title: StaTuesday: Target Center records
text:
FOXSPORTS StaTuesday: Target Center records On the 25th anniversary of the Target Center, we run down the list of records set at the arena, a couple of which have stood since that opening season. 
Timberwolves forward Kevin Love had 31 points and a Target Center-record 31 rebounds in a 2010 win over the Knicks. Brace Hemmelgarn / USA TODAY Sports By Dave Heller Oct 13, 2015 at 1:00p ET 0Shares 
The Target Center turned 25 on Tuesday and the home of the Minnesota Timbewolves will be around for years to come, thanks to renovations. 
The arena has seen its share of great performances over the years. Below we list the all-time bests in a number of statistical categories. If the record is by an opponent, we've tried to include the Minnesota record as well. You'll note a couple of records have stood since that opening season and they were set by current Timberwolves interim assistant coach Sam Mitchell. 
A few other records have been around for over 20 years while a couple marks were set last season. Will any records fall this season? 
Here's the list of Target Center records: 
Most points: 55 -- San Antonio's Tony Parker , Nov. 5, 2008 (2 OT); 51 -- Corey Brewer vs. Houston , April 11, 2014 
Most field goals: 22 -- San Antonio's Tony Parker, Nov. 5, 2008 (2 OT); 19 -- Wally Szczerbiak vs. Chicago, April 13, 2003, Kevin Garnett vs. Phoenix, April 4, 2005, Corey Brewer vs. Houston, April 11, 2014 
Highest field-goal percentage: .923 -- Miami's Hassan Whiteside (12 of 13), Feb. 4, 2015; .917 -- Kevin Garnett (11 of 12) vs. Dallas, March 30, 1999, Rasho Nesterovic (11 of 12) vs. Phoenix, Jan. 13, 1999. 
Most 3-point field goals: 9 -- Miami's Dan Marjele, Jan. 11, 2000, Boston's Antoine Walker, Nov. 9, 2002, Golden State's Dorell Wright, Nov. 27, 2010; 7 -- Most recently Kevin Martin vs. New York, Nov. 19, 2014 
Most free throws made: 18 -- Christian Laettner vs. Sacramento, Feb. 18, 1993, Kevin Love vs. Golden State, Feb. 27, 2011 
Highest free-throw percentage: 1.000 --- Orlando's Grant Hill (17 of 17), Nov. 1, 2002; Michael Williams (16 of 16) vs. Indians, April, 7, 1993
